attr.q: Now that we know \lim x_n exists, explan why \lim x_{n+1} must also exist and equal the same value.
Take the limit of each side of the recursive equation in part (a) to explicitly compute \lim x_n.
attr.a:
Let's say \lim x_n = x, then

\begin {aligned} & x = \frac 1 {4-x} \\ & \rightarrow 4x - x^2 - 1=0 \end {aligned}

Solve quadratic equation, you get 2 \pm \sqrt3. But it has to be less than 3 so the answer is 2-\sqrt3 \approx 0.2679491924311227

attr.q:
Prove that the sequence defined by x_1 = 3 and

x_{n+1} = {1 \over 4 - x_n}

converges.
attr.a:
1. (x_n) is decreasing.

Proof (by Induction)

The base case is that x_0 = 3 > x_1 = 1

The induction step is that

\begin{aligned} & x_n > x_{n+1} \\ & \rightarrow -x_n < -x_{n+1} \\ & \rightarrow 4-x_n < 4-x_{n+1} \\ & \rightarrow \frac 1 {4-x_n} > \frac 1 {4-x_{n+1}} \end{aligned}

... hence decrease (monotonic).

2. (x_n) is bounded.

Let's express x_n in fraction

x_n = \frac {a_n} {b_n}

then x_{n+1} is

\begin{aligned} & x_{n+1} \\ & = \frac 1 {4-x_n} \\ & = \frac 1 {4 - \frac {a_n} {b_n}} \\ & = \frac 1 {\frac {4b_n - a_n} {b_n}} \\ & = \frac {b_n} {4b_n - a_n} \\ & = \frac {4b_n - a_n + a_n} {4(4b_n - a_n)} \\ & = \frac 1 4 + \frac {a_n} {4(4b_n - a_n)} \\ \end{aligned}

0 \leq a_n \leq 4b_n therefore

0 \leq \frac {a_n} {4(4b_n - a_n)}

It means 1/4 is a lower bound.

(1) and (2) satisfys the Monotone Convergence Theorem. Therefore (x_n) converges.
